subject: RE: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals urgently)
msgSnippet: ... To clarify my sentence above, the last word it equates to things written on the site about exploratory testing, as well as a lot of negatives about test
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
> Sent: Thursday, August 28, 2003 2:50 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit
> professionals urgently)
>
>
> Michael Silverstein wrote:
>
> >
> >>From: Curt Sampson [mailto:yahoo_sucks@...]
> >>
> >>On Tue, 26 Aug 2003, Michael Silverstein wrote:
> >>
> >>
> >>>The good part of ET is that you spend less time coming up
> >>
> >>with scripts
> >>
> >>>and automating and more time testing, so you have a greater
> >>
> >>liklihood
> >>
> >>>of going down a path you might not otherwise have tested.
> >>
> >>Actually, I've found that without the scripts I spend less
> >>time testing, because doing a test similar to a previous test
> >>but with just a couple of things changed isn't just a matter
> >>if a quick cut, paste and run.
> >
> > Personally I'm not a fan of exploratory testing but I like
> to say at
> > least one thing nice about something before listing things I don't
> > like about it. For a better defense of ET and discussion of the
> > limitation of automation than I could ever provide, you should read
> > some of Cem Kaner's articles on http://www.kaner.com/. Note that I
> > don't agree with a lot of it.
>
> Can we see the list of things you don't like, too?
>

To clarify my sentence above, the last word "it" equates to things
written on the site about exploratory testing, as well as a lot of
negatives about test automation. I already mentioned what I don't like
about ET in my previous append and this group/XP/agile people can
articulate the advantages of automation better than I. If you want to
dig, Mr. Kaner and I went back and forth a bit in on this subject in
January of this year on the software-testing group. Of course there's
always more to be said but not enough time. Anyway, to reiterate a
different append of mine, if you want to have a good/fun/heated
conversation on these subjects with peple who have very strong, well
earned opinions you should take this subject to the sodtware-testing
group.
